commentaries.text:
Welcome to Gavin Ortlund's commentary on the Book of Revelation from his video 'Explaining Every Chapter of Revelation'.

The Book of Revelation is one of the most fascinating and challenging books of the Bible. It was written by the apostle John while he was exiled on the island of Patmos. The book contains apocalyptic visions that reveal God's ultimate plan for humanity and creation.

To get the full commentary, please ensure the DOCX file is in the project root and run 'npm run parse-docx'.

Chapter 1 introduces us to the Book of Revelation with a prologue and John's vision of the glorified Christ. The chapter establishes the divine authority behind this revelation and presents Jesus in His exalted, heavenly state.

The opening verses establish the chain of revelation: from God to Jesus Christ to His angel to John to the servants (believers). This shows both the divine origin and the intended audience of this prophecy.

Verse 3 contains the first of seven beatitudes in Revelation: 'Blessed is he who reads and those who hear the words of the prophecy.' This emphasizes that Revelation was meant to be read aloud in churches and taken seriously by believers.

John greets the seven churches with a Trinitarian blessing. The phrase 'who is and who was and who is to come' emphasizes God's eternal nature. The seven Spirits likely refer to the Holy Spirit in His fullness.

Jesus is described as the faithful witness, the firstborn from the dead, and the ruler of kings. Verse 7 contains one of the key themes of Revelation: Christ's visible return that all will witness.

John's vision of the glorified Christ is breathtaking. The imagery draws from Daniel's vision of the 'Ancient of Days' and 'one like a son of man.' Jesus walks among the seven golden lampstands (the churches), showing His active presence with His people.

The description of Christ with white hair, eyes like fire, feet like bronze, and a voice like many waters emphasizes His divine majesty, purity, judgment, and authority. The two-edged sword from His mouth represents the power of His word.

Chapters 2 and 3 contain the seven letters to the seven churches in Asia Minor. Each letter follows a similar pattern: an address, a description of Christ, commendation (for most), criticism (for most), exhortation, and a promise to the overcomer.

These churches represent real historical congregations but also serve as examples of various spiritual conditions that can exist in churches throughout history.

The church at Ephesus is commended for their hard work, perseverance, and discernment against false apostles. However, they had forsaken their first love - the passionate devotion to Christ they once had.

This serves as a warning that theological correctness and hard work are not enough; love for Christ must remain central to our faith.

The church in Smyrna receives no criticism - only encouragement in the face of persecution. They are materially poor but spiritually rich. Jesus, who died and came to life, promises that faithful endurance through suffering will be rewarded with the crown of life.

Pergamum is where 'Satan's throne' is - likely referring to the prominence of emperor worship there. The church is commended for holding fast to Christ's name even when Antipas was martyred.

However, some tolerate the teaching of Balaam and the Nicolaitans - compromising with idolatry and immorality. The promise of 'hidden manna' and a 'white stone' speaks of intimate fellowship with Christ.

Thyatira receives the longest letter. They are growing in love, faith, and service. Yet they tolerate 'Jezebel' - a woman promoting sexual immorality and eating food sacrificed to idols.

The promise to the overcomer includes authority over nations and 'the morning star' - which Revelation 22:16 identifies as Jesus Himself.

Sardis has a reputation for being alive but is actually dead - a sobering warning about spiritual complacency. They are called to wake up, strengthen what remains, and remember what they received.

The few who have not 'soiled their garments' will walk with Christ in white. The overcomer's name will not be blotted from the book of life.

Philadelphia, like Smyrna, receives no criticism. Though they have 'little power,' they have kept Christ's word and not denied His name. Christ has set before them an open door no one can shut.

The promise to keep them from 'the hour of testing' and to make overcomers pillars in God's temple with God's name written on them speaks of permanent security and belonging.

Laodicea is the only church receiving no commendation. They are lukewarm - neither hot nor cold - causing Christ to want to 'spit them out.' They think they are rich but are actually wretched, poor, blind, and naked.

Yet even here, Christ's love persists: 'Those whom I love, I reprove and discipline.' The famous image of Christ standing at the door and knocking is actually addressed to a church! The overcomer will sit with Christ on His throne.
Chapter 4 marks a transition in the book. John is called up to heaven to see 'what must take place after this.' The throne room vision reveals God's sovereignty and the worship of heaven.

The throne room scene is filled with rich symbolism. The twenty-four elders likely represent the complete people of God (12 tribes + 12 apostles). The four living creatures recall Ezekiel's vision and represent all of creation worshiping God.

The constant refrain 'Holy, holy, holy' emphasizes God's absolute purity and transcendence. Everything in this chapter points to God's worthiness to be worshiped as Creator.

Chapter 5 introduces the scroll sealed with seven seals - representing God's plan for history and redemption. The dramatic question 'Who is worthy to open the scroll?' is answered: only the Lamb who was slain.

John weeps because no one seems worthy to open the scroll. But then the Lion of Judah appears - yet when John looks, he sees a Lamb that appears to have been slain. This paradox is central to understanding Jesus: He conquers through sacrifice.

The Lamb's seven horns represent complete power; seven eyes represent complete knowledge and the Spirit's presence. The song 'Worthy is the Lamb' celebrates Christ's redemption of people from every tribe, language, and nation.

Chapter 6 begins the opening of the seven seals. The first four seals release the famous 'four horsemen' representing conquest, war, famine, and death. These judgments reveal the consequences of human sin and rebellion.

The four horsemen represent forces that have plagued humanity throughout history. The white horse may represent false peace or conquest. The red horse brings war and violence. The black horse brings economic hardship and famine. The pale horse is Death itself, followed by Hades.

These judgments, while terrifying, are limited - showing God's restraint even in judgment.

The fifth seal reveals the martyrs under the altar, crying out for justice. God's answer is that they must wait - more believers will join them before the end.

The sixth seal brings cosmic upheaval. The powerful of the earth try to hide from 'the wrath of the Lamb' - a striking phrase that combines the gentle image of a lamb with terrifying judgment.
Chapter 7 is an interlude between the sixth and seventh seals. It provides assurance that God's people are protected and will ultimately triumph, even through great tribulation.

The 144,000 sealed from Israel and the great multitude from every nation are likely two ways of describing the same group - the complete people of God. They have come through the great tribulation and stand victorious before God's throne.

The beautiful promise in verses 15-17 assures believers that all suffering will end: no more hunger, thirst, or tears. The Lamb will be their shepherd.
Chapter 8 opens the seventh seal, which contains the seven trumpet judgments. After a dramatic silence in heaven, the trumpets begin to sound, bringing intensified judgments upon the earth.

The half-hour of silence in heaven creates dramatic tension. The prayers of the saints, mixed with incense, rise before God - showing that believers' prayers play a role in God's plan.

The trumpet judgments echo the plagues of Egypt. Hail and fire, a burning mountain, a falling star (Wormwood), and darkened luminaries devastate portions of the earth. The eagle's cry of 'Woe, woe, woe!' warns that worse is coming.
Chapter 9 describes the fifth and sixth trumpet judgments - terrifying demonic plagues that torment and kill vast numbers of people. Yet remarkably, survivors still refuse to repent.

The fifth trumpet releases locust-like creatures from the abyss, led by Abaddon/Apollyon (Destroyer). They torment unbelievers for five months - people will seek death but not find it.

The sixth trumpet releases four angels bound at the Euphrates, who lead a vast army that kills a third of humanity. Yet the survivors do not repent of their idolatry, murders, sorcery, immorality, or theft. The human heart's hardness is sobering.
Chapter 10 is another interlude, introducing a mighty angel with a little scroll. John is commissioned to prophesy again, suggesting more revelation to come.

The mighty angel, wrapped in a cloud with a rainbow and face like the sun, straddles sea and land - indicating universal authority. The seven thunders speak, but John is told not to write what they said.

John eats the little scroll - sweet in his mouth but bitter in his stomach. God's word is both sweet (gospel) and bitter (judgment). John must prophesy to many peoples, nations, languages, and kings.
Chapter 11 describes the two witnesses who prophesy for 1,260 days, are killed, and then resurrected. The seventh trumpet announces the kingdom of God.

The two witnesses - described as olive trees and lampstands - likely represent the witnessing church throughout history. They have power like Moses and Elijah. When they finish their testimony, the beast kills them, but after three and a half days they are resurrected and ascend to heaven.

The seventh trumpet brings the announcement: 'The kingdom of the world has become the kingdom of our Lord and of his Christ, and he will reign forever and ever!' The heavenly temple opens, revealing the ark of the covenant.

Chapter 12 presents cosmic drama: the woman (representing God's people/Israel/the church), the dragon (Satan), and the male child (Christ). This chapter gives the spiritual background to the earthly events described elsewhere.

The dragon's attempt to destroy the child and the woman shows Satan's opposition to God's redemptive plan throughout history. The child (Christ) is caught up to God's throne - a reference to His ascension.

Verse 11 is key: believers overcome the dragon 'by the blood of the Lamb and by the word of their testimony.' Victory comes through faith in Christ's sacrifice and faithful witness, even unto death.

Chapter 13 introduces the two beasts - the beast from the sea (political/military power) and the beast from the earth (religious/ideological deception). Together with the dragon, they form an unholy trinity opposing God.

The first beast combines features from Daniel's four beasts, representing the cumulative power of world empires opposed to God. Its apparent death and resurrection parodies Christ's resurrection.

The second beast promotes worship of the first beast and institutes the famous 'mark of the beast.' The number 666 likely points to imperfection (falling short of 7) or may have referred to a specific ruler like Nero.

The mark represents allegiance to the beast's system rather than to God. Throughout history, believers have faced pressure to conform to anti-God systems.
Chapter 14 provides encouragement amid the beast's reign. The 144,000 stand victorious with the Lamb, angels proclaim judgment, and the harvest of the earth is depicted.

The 144,000 have the Lamb's name and His Father's name on their foreheads - contrasting with the mark of the beast. They sing a new song that only they can learn.

Three angels proclaim eternal gospel, announce Babylon's fall, and warn against worshiping the beast. Verse 13 offers comfort: 'Blessed are the dead who die in the Lord.' The chapter ends with vivid harvest imagery of judgment.
Chapter 15 prepares for the seven bowl judgments - the final outpouring of God's wrath. The overcomers sing the song of Moses and the Lamb.

Those who have conquered the beast stand on a sea of glass mixed with fire, singing of God's great and marvelous works. The song celebrates God's righteous acts that will cause all nations to worship Him.

Seven angels emerge from the heavenly temple with the seven final plagues. The temple fills with smoke from God's glory - no one can enter until the plagues are complete.
Chapter 16 records the seven bowl judgments - rapid, intense, and final expressions of God's wrath on an unrepentant world.

The bowl judgments echo the plagues of Egypt but are universal and complete. Painful sores, seas and rivers turning to blood, scorching heat, darkness, and the gathering at Armageddon all precede the final 'It is done!'

Despite the severity, people continue to blaspheme God rather than repent. The seventh bowl brings the greatest earthquake ever, and 100-pound hailstones. Babylon the great is remembered for judgment.
Chapter 17 unveils the great prostitute, Babylon, riding on the beast. The vision reveals the corrupt alliance between religious/economic systems and political power that opposes God.

The prostitute sits on many waters (peoples and nations), drunk with the blood of saints. She represents human civilization in rebellion against God - seductive, powerful, and corrupt.

The seven heads are seven hills (Rome) and seven kings. The beast and the kings will eventually turn on the prostitute and destroy her - evil ultimately devours itself. The Lamb will overcome them all because He is Lord of lords and King of kings.
Chapter 18 is a funeral dirge for Babylon. Kings, merchants, and sailors mourn her fall while heaven rejoices.

Babylon falls in one hour. The detailed list of luxury goods (gold, silver, spices, slaves, 'human souls') exposes the greed and exploitation at the heart of the Babylonian system.

'Come out of her, my people' - believers must not participate in Babylon's sins. The finality of judgment is emphasized: the sounds of music, craftsmen, and weddings will never be heard in her again. She is guilty of the blood of prophets and saints.
Chapter 19 brings triumphant celebration in heaven over Babylon's fall, the wedding supper of the Lamb, and Christ's victorious return as King of kings and Lord of lords.

The fourfold 'Hallelujah!' in heaven celebrates God's just judgment and the arrival of the Lamb's wedding. The bride (the church) has made herself ready, clothed in fine linen representing the righteous deeds of the saints.

Christ returns as the victorious warrior on a white horse. His names - Faithful and True, The Word of God, King of Kings and Lord of Lords - declare His nature and authority. The battle is one-sided; the beast and false prophet are thrown into the lake of fire.
Chapter 20 describes the thousand-year reign (millennium), Satan's final rebellion, and the Great White Throne judgment. Christians have interpreted the millennium differently throughout history.

Satan is bound for a thousand years, preventing him from deceiving the nations. Believers reign with Christ during this period. After the thousand years, Satan is released for a final rebellion, which is quickly defeated.

The Great White Throne judgment is the final judgment of all humanity. Death and Hades are thrown into the lake of fire - this is 'the second death.' Only those written in the book of life escape this fate.
Chapter 21 unveils the new heaven and new earth - the glorious destiny of God's people. The New Jerusalem descends from heaven, beautiful as a bride, where God dwells with His people forever.

The new creation is marked by what is absent: no more sea (chaos), no more death, mourning, crying, or pain. God Himself wipes away every tear.

God declares 'Behold, I am making all things new' - not making all new things, but renewing and redeeming creation. The promise to the overcomer is intimate: 'I will be his God and he will be my son.'

The New Jerusalem's description is stunning - a perfect cube like the Holy of Holies, but vast in scale. The twelve gates named for Israel's tribes and twelve foundations named for the apostles show continuity between old and new covenants.

There is no temple because God and the Lamb are its temple. No sun or moon because God's glory illuminates it. The gates never close because there is no threat. This is the ultimate fulfillment of God dwelling with His people.
The final chapter completes the vision of the New Jerusalem and concludes Revelation with promises, warnings, and the invitation to 'Come.'

The river of life and tree of life recall Eden, showing that paradise is restored and exceeded. The curse is removed; God's servants will see His face and reign forever.

The book ends with urgency: 'I am coming quickly.' The Spirit and the Bride say 'Come!' - both an invitation to unbelievers and a prayer for Christ's return.

John's response - 'Amen. Come, Lord Jesus!' - should be the prayer of every believer. The book that began with blessing ends with grace.
